awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Early Career Principal Investigator Coring Training Cruise
awd_abstract_narration:
Collection and analysis of seafloor sediment samples is a fundamental tool in marine geology. Sediment sampling is key to the study of earthquake hazards, climate change, and the deep biosphere. This project will focus on training scientists for seafloor sampling best practices. Practices encompass planning and executing an oceanographic field expedition involving collection of deep-sea marine sediments. The shore-based training will introduce participants to critical aspects of cruise planning and site selection. Such selection uses basic geophysical techniques, access to data, and use of core repositories. Participants will design a science-driven cruise plan with guidance from an experienced team of mentors. Then, the participants will sail on a UNOLS global class vessel to gain hands-on experience. The experience includes working with site survey, sampling equipment, and shipboard data collection. The training will conclude ashore with a review of the scientific outcomes of the cruise. The post-cruise component will allow for hands-on training. The training will include analytical, interpretive and archival techniques. The training will set the stage for efficient and successful future research using the collected materials. Participant selection will focus on promoting equity and diversity in marine geoscience. 

In August of 2019 a detailed survey was conducted to quantify interest in early career coring training for prospective NSF principal investigators. Nearly a hundred responses were submitted in a period of less than two weeks, highlighting community need and demand for a training opportunity that encompasses cruise planning, site selection, shipboard operations, core processing and curation. This proposal is to provide a sediment coring principal investigator (PI) training for early career scientists (ECS). Training will consist of a coupled workshop and field program: a field-based coring program of ten days aboard a UNOLS vessel to be directed by the early-career participants, bracketed by week-long pre-and post-cruise workshops. In the pre-cruise workshop participants will plan the cruise and select sites to be cored with the support and guidance of a team of experienced mentors. They will be trained in the utility of legacy data at the Oregon State University Marine Geology Repository (OSU MGR). They will also be introduced to the NSF Marine Sediment Sampling (MARSSAM) facility and the technical and logistical support offered to NSF coring PI’s by MARSSAM staff. At sea, participants will be trained in the operation and deployment of various coring systems, chirp and multi-beam data acquisition and interpretation, final site selection, core processing, multi-sensor core logger data collection and interpretation, and shipboard core description and curation. At the post-cruise workshop, senior mentors will guide participants through interpretation of core descriptions, integration of collected cores and preliminary physical property data with the stratigraphic/depositional environment.  Participants will also be introduced to relevant analytical techniques and appropriate archival, sampling and data management practices.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This proposal funded a shore-based workshop and training cruise for NSF Principal Investigators with a research focus on collecting seafloor sediment samples. The training supported 24 participants from 22 institutions across the country and included 11 early to mid-career faculty (Assistant/Associate Professor), 11 post-doctoral scholars, and 2 graduate students with leadership roles in near-future NSF-supported research cruises requiring sediment coring. Solicitations for participation were made through professional associations, social media, and on the University National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) website. An effort was made to recruit participation from smaller academic institutions. Approximately 44% of participants were women, and 36% were members of racial and/or cultural demographic minorities. 

The pre-cruise workshop was hosted by Oregon State University at the Marine and Geology Repository, and featured mentorship from experienced mid to late career researchers across a range of related disciplines from Oregon State University, University of Washington, Scripps Institution of Oceanography, Texas A&M University, Rutgers University, Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution, and Columbia University Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory. During the pre-cruise workshop, participants were first introduced to University-National Oceanographic Laboratory System (UNOLS) facilities and Academic Research Fleet (ARF) platforms. On the second day, participants were introduced to techniques and tools for bathymetric survey and site selection, with an emphasis on accessing and utilizing legacy data for efficient pre-cruise planning. The third day focused on capitalizing on the resources of the NSF core repositories both in cruise planning and in archival of newly recovered materials. This included covering curation practices, searching and utilizing the digitized core collections, and introduction to fundamental non-destructive analyses that allow for rapid focusing of post-cruise science and extend the useful life of recovered cores. On the fourth day, participants developed hands-on experience in the various stages of core processing, starting with non-destructive scanning for physical properties, through splitting, description and imaging. The fifth day of the workshop focused on the practicalities of planning a research cruise, and featured an introduction to pre-cruise planning meetings from the lead resident technician at Scripps Institution of Oceanography as well as an introduction to the functions of the UNOLS Marine Facilities Planner by the UNOLS Deputy Executive Secretary. The day ended with a review of the geologic and oceanographic setting of the Oregon margin and review of strategic goals for the upcoming training cruise. On the final day of the pre-cruise workshop, participants broke out into smaller groups organized based on shared interests and developed collaborative cruise proposals leveraging the tools and strategies that were the focus of the previous week.

The mentors and workshop participants then traveled to Newport, OR to join the R/V Roger Revelle for a 10-day research cruise to develop hands-on experience with a range of coring systems, as well as site survey and strategy development, post-recovery non-destructive physical-properties measurement collection, and core curation at sea. Coring was attempted from a variety of sedimentary environments, ranging from the shallow shelf to the abyssal plain and including methane seep environments, records of past earthquakes and slope failures, and targets for paleoceanographic reconstructions. Recovered cores were returned to the Oregon State University Marine and Geology Repository after the cruise, and a short post-cruise workshop focused on reviewing the goals, strategies, and results from each of the coring targets attempted before the participants returned to their home institutions. Non-destructive scans for physical properties, CT-scan imaging and bulk sediment composition (for select cores) were conducted, and any recovered materials that were not split and described at sea were archived by Marine and Geology Repository Staff for ingestion into the repository.

Following the cruise, workshop participants have remained in active contact, with at least three NSF proposals for future coring cruises submitted resulting from the cruise planning exercises and connections built during the workshop. Five participants have already had or will be leading NSF-funded coring cruises aboard ARF platforms in the next year. A number of workshop participants have planned future research with cores and pore water samples recovered from the training cruise, with one team visiting the repository for subsampling in April of 2023, another team planning a sampling visit for summer 2023, and another has put in a request for samples collected from a seep core for post-expedition research. Feedback on the success of training goals was solicited in the form of an anonymous online survey, and was overall highly positive, with all respondents (23 of the 24 participants) indicating they would recommend this training to colleagues.
